Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Novel Assistive Robot Arm for Collaborative Research in Assistive and Rehabilitation Robotics at a Predominantly Undergraduate Institution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a shared state-of-the-art JACO-2 robot arm for collaborative research in assistive and rehabilitation robotics, aims to improve the quality of life of individuals with disabilities and the elderly by increasing their independence and community reintegration. It supports research in three areas:
- Assistive technology and vocational rehabilitation systems;
- Robotics and control systems; and
- Health monitoring systems.
In these areas, the participating researchers will use the equipment collaboratively on diverse research projects. In addition, the award should facilitate development of assistive robotics research and training across multiple departments.

This novel instrument enables access by the research community to an instrument that will accelerate research in assistive robotics, vocational rehabilitation, health-care and monitoring, and home care. The proposed projects introduce a simple robot arm manipulation scheme for enabling the incorporation of robotic systems into home environment, thus enhancing the independence and autonomy of individuals with disabilities, and minimizing the necessity for a caregiver. The research projects will also contribute to assisting the elderly and persons with disability to manipulate and communicate with the robot in complex unstructured environments, thereby enhancing safety and reliability of the robotic system, especially for people with lower or upper limb limitations or both lower and upper limb limitations to perform tasks in a more complicated workplace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project lies in the JACO2 instrument that has accelerated our research in assistive robotics, vocational rehabilitation, health-care and monitoring, and home care, especially for people with lower or upper limb limitations to perform tasks in a complicated personal living space and workplace. The broader accomplishments of this project include: 1) providing access to shared instrumentation for research and training of faculty and students; 2) developing interdisciplinary and collaborative research opportunities on our campus; 3) leveraging individual research funding in a mainly undergraduate-serving institution and foster the integration of research and education; 4) offering outreach opportunities for area primary, middle, and high schools, as well as area college students, to learn basic techniques with robotics.

The University of Wisconsin Stout has established a Research Experience for Undergraduate Research site (REU) in Robotics for Assistive Technology over the 3-year period (2016-2018). The acquisition of a novel robotic arm  JACO2 has facilitated our undergraduate research with REU. The REU project brings together a dynamic and creative group of 24 undergraduates from universities across the country in an intensive 8-week summer program. The following research activities were based off the JACO2 instrument that aims to improve the quality of life for people with upper limb disabilities. The roles of the PI and Co-PI were instructors and mentors for providing research experiences to the 24 undergraduate students. Following  activities are selected research efforts accomplsihed by our students and faculty mentors: 

Research Activity#1: Development of JACO2 Robot Arm Interface with Wheelchair

Research Activity#2: Semi-Autonomous Meal Assistance Robot

Research Activity#3: The Accuracy, Effectiveness, and Quality of Life of the JACO2 Robotic Arm Impacts on Wheelchair Users

Research Activity 4: Autonomous Meal Assistance Robot using Facial gestures and Voice Commands

The robot system has been developed using the Kinova JACO arm and tested with both able-bodied users and an individual with an upper extremity disability. It has been developed to be portable instead of being tethered to a table and wall power sockets. In addition to this, a library of commands has been created, where different facial features control different movements of the arm. This work has been extended to use voice control instead of facial features to control the robot. Also, utensils that work better with the robot have been developed for the robot?s gripper.



Last Modified: 10/30/2018
Modified by: Cheng Liu
